text: ? I understand what a graph is. The point is to show why I found Rust difficult with an example and why an alternative is appealing to me personally.

text:
I'd like to take a closer look at your example tomorrow. I can't parse what usize is doing there anyways..

I feel like the type system in rust is different to the type system you have in your mind. I too have an example like this, where I went with generic code all the way, and it made me go away from generics, not from rust..

elements.text:

text: do people tend to avoid generics in Rust? if so then I'd feel less bad about myself, because that's where things got heavy/unexpected.

elements.text: do people tend to avoid generics in Rust? if so then I'd feel less bad about myself, because that's where things got heavy/unexpected.

text: I think APIs in any language mostly use generics, even C++ does this

text: I think you can use a RefCell to easily make nodes & friends. But there's some cases you need to drop data manually, or else you get memory leaks.

elements.text: I think you can use a RefCell to easily make nodes & friends. But there's some cases you need to drop data manually, or else you get memory leaks.

text: yeah it shouldn't be possible in Rust to leak anything stack allocated and pinned, maybe unless a function diverges or something

elements.text: yeah it shouldn't be possible in Rust to leak anything stack allocated and pinned, maybe unless a function diverges or something

text: was going to say I don't see why there's a need to use unsafe code to make a graph

elements.text: was going to say I don't see why there's a need to use unsafe code to make a graph

text: You can force several kinds of Undefined Behaviors (UB). The intermediate way of making a graph would be something that count references to a node and can have it's value replace. The low level would be using lots of raw pointers and unsafe keyword.

elements.text: You can force several kinds of Undefined Behaviors (UB). The intermediate way of making a graph would be something that count references to a node and can have it's value replace. The low level would be using lots of raw pointers and unsafe keyword.

text: Using such low level approach, you reach the same issues as plain C/C++ and segfault easily.

elements.text: Using such low level approach, you reach the same issues as plain C/C++ and segfault easily.

text: there are plenty of operations on graphs I would consider not being possible to do safely
